Dear Annetra Jones:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
Section (1) An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
Description parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
1

(a) A plan of visitation for each child in foster care consistent
with the child’s service plans, as required by R 400.12419 and R
400.12420 to assure the safety and wellbeing of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Despite evidence that the mother put the children at risk by
exposing them to assault and weapons, the agency permitted
visits between the mother and children at the home.
Investigation
DHHS Supervisor/Complainant was interviewed via Teams on
4/13/2023. She reported she supervised the worker who
investigated an October 2022 incident during which Parent A &
Relative A showed up at Parent B’s home with a knife, guns, and
brass knuckles and assaulted Parent B’s girlfriend. Foster Care
Supervisor and Foster Care worker were made aware of the
investigation concerns and findings. DHHS Supervisor stated
there were also multiple criminal charges filed as a result of the
incident, which are still pending. Additionally, during a police raid
after the incident, multiple weapons, including semi-automatic
firearms stored in a closet, were located in Relative A’s home.
DHHS Supervisor stated Youth A & Youth B reported where the
semi-automatic weapons were kept. DHHS Supervisor reported
there were multiple meetings and interactions with the agency
staff throughout and after the investigation.
DHHS Supervisor reported DHHS worker and Foster Care Worker
planned to remove the youths from Relative A’s home after the
incident. DHHS worker and Foster Care Worker went to Relative
A’s home to move the children and Relative A attempted to take
off with the children in her car. DHHS worker used her car to block
Relative A and the police arrived after which the children were
removed from Relative A and placed with Relative B.
DHHS Supervisor stated agency staff have told her Parent A
refuses to go to the agency for her visits and Relative B can no
longer have the visits at her home, so the visits started to take
place at Relative A’s home. During a visit at that home on
4/3/2023 which was being supervised by Case Aide, Relative A
and Parent A took off with kids, threatened Case Aide, and
potentially had weapons. DHHS Supervisor expressed her serious
concern with the decision to allow the visits to occur in Relative
A’s home due to Parent A and Relative A’s history of violence,
weapons, and DHHS findings. DHHS Supervisor stated agency
staff have not been able to provide rationale as to why they
believe Relative A’s home is a safe place for visits.
2

DHHS Worker was interviewed via Teams on 4/13/2023. DHHS
Worker stated that Foster Care Worker was the assigned worker
during the 10/30/2022 incident and was well aware of the DHHS
findings; however, Relative A continued to attend visits with mom.
She reported that on 4/5/2023, during a meeting, Foster Care
Supervisor and Foster Care Worker were reminded of DHHS
findings and pending criminal charges against Relative A following
the October 2022 incident. DHHS Worker reported she is involved
in another incident that occurred in February during which Parent
B allowed Relative A to pick the youths up from daycare. Relative
A was supposed to return the youths to Parent B, but she and
Parent A kept the youths overnight.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via Teams on
4/13/2023. She reported Youth A and Youth B were placed with
their maternal grandmother, Relative A, until the court ordered the
children be returned to their father, Parent B, in October 2022.
She stated Youth A & Youth B’s mother, Parent A, now lives with
Relative A. Foster Care Supervisor stated, after the youths were
returned to Parent B, Parent A continued to have supervised
visits. These visits were occurring either at Parent A’s great-aunt
home, Relative B’s home or at Relative A’s home and were
supervised by agency staff. Foster Care Supervisor reported she
is aware of the DHHS investigation involving Relative A and
Parent A in which it was determined they assaulted Parent B’s
LTP in front of Parent B’s home on October 30, 2022. Foster Care
Supervisor stated she was aware Parent A had a knife during the
incident and Relative A “maybe” had a gun but stated Relative A
has a license to carry so she was allowed to have the gun;
however, she stated she did not know how the gun was used
during the incident. Foster Care Supervisor stated Youth’s A and
Youth B were present during the assault; however, she did not
feel they were at any risk of harm because they were in the car.
Foster Care Supervisor stated, despite the DHHS investigation
resulting in a preponderance of evidence to support findings
against Relative A and Parent A, Foster Care Supervisor
determined Relative A was safe and appropriate and the findings
did not have anything to do with neglect or abuse of Youth A &
Youth B; however, when asked which children were involved in
the findings, she stated Youth A & Youth B. She stated the DHHS
investigation was completed after the youths were already placed
with Parent B, so there was no need to remove from Relative A.
Foster Care Supervisor stated that Relative A’s home was “never
unsafe” and visits in her home were always supervised. She
3

added there were never any concerns with the children being
placed in the home or subsequent visits occurring in the home.
She stated a visit took place 4/3/2023 in Relative A’s home during
which the youths disclosed being inappropriately touched. This
disclosure was made to Parent A as she was bathing the youths.
Case Aide, who was supervising the visit, called Program
Manager to inform her of the disclosure and subsequently offered
to take the youth to the hospital for examination. Foster Care
Supervisor received a call from Program Manager after which she
called DHHS with the allegation. Foster Care Supervisor stated
Parent A & Relative A took off with the youths in their car and
brought them to the hospital. Foster Care Supervisor called the
police, who stated they were not going to dispatch anyone if the
youths were being brought to the hospital. Foster Care Supervisor
stated she doesn’t know why, but Case Aide did not follow Parent
A & Relative A to the hospital; however, Foster Care Worker did
go to the hospital where she stayed with the youths.
Foster Care Supervisor was asked if she was aware Case Aide
felt threatened by Parent A and Relative A prior to them leaving
with the children. She stated she does not feel that Case Aide was
threatened, rather, Parent A and Relative A made Case Aide “feel
uncomfortable” and “maybe outside of her personal comfort zone.”
Foster Care Supervisor stated Case Aide was aware of Relative A
& Parent A’s investigation history and has been supervising their
visit for quite a while.
Case Aide was interviewed by phone on 4/13/2023. She reported
she has been supervising Parent A’s visits since June of 2022.
She stated Parent A stopped visiting for a while then resumed
visitation in October of 2022. Case Aide reported Parent A’s visits
were sporadic and initially took place at the agency, then took
place at Relative B’s home. Sometime after December, the visits
started occurring in Relative A’s home. Case Aide stated the visits
were appropriate and she had never felt unsafe in the home until
the 4/3/2023 visit. During the visit, Youth A & Youth B made a
disclosure of being inappropriately touched to Parent A who
started crying and became angry and upset. Case Aide assisted
her in making a call to DHHS, which went fine. When Case Aide
told Parent A that Case Aide could drive the youths to the hospital
for examination and Parent A could follow her, Parent A became
angry and told Case Aide she would drive her own children to the
hospital while Case Aide followed. Parent A told Case Aide to “get
the fuck out,” then got into Case Aide’s face, yelling, which Case
Aide found threatening. Case Aide stated that Parent A put her
4

hand into her own pocket while getting into Case Aide’s face,
which made Case Aide concerned about a potential weapon. She
stated she is used to Parent A getting loud and yelling, which
Case Aide doesn’t find threatening, but her gestures and body
language during this incident were threatening. Case Aide stated
Parent A and Relative A kept going into different rooms of the
house where Case Aide could not see them and would not
respond to Case Aide. At one point, Case Aide heard Youth B say
“I saw your toy gun” to Parent A while they were in another room,
so she was unsure what Parent A and Relative A were doing.
Parent A and Relative A then left the home with the youths. Case
Aide followed them until they got to the freeway.
Case Aide stated she had been made aware of the October
incident and investigation involving Relative A and Parent A. She
stated that she questioned why the visits would occur in Relative
A’s home after that incident and was told it was ok since the
altercation in October happened outside of Parent B’s home. Case
Aide thought this odd since she also picks up and drops off the
youths from Parent B’s home, but continued to supervise those
visits at Relative A’s home as it was not her decision.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via Teams on 4/19/2023.
She reported Youth A & Youth B were placed in Relative A’s
home in July of 2020. She stated that the youths were ordered to
be returned to Parent B in October of 2022. Foster Care Worker
was transitioning the youth to Parent B’s home during which
Parent B continued to have unsupervised weekend visits. Relative
A would meet Parent B at a local police station for pick-up and
drop-off for the visits. Foster Care Worker doesn’t know the
reason why, but on 10/30/2022, Relative A told Parent B she
would pick the youths up from his home. Parent B had previously
informed Parent A, Caregiver A, and Foster Care Worker that one
of the youths had sustained an injury while playing during his
visitation. When Relative A arrived at Parent B’s home to pick up
the youths, she had Parent A in the car, which was not approved
by Foster Care Worker. Parent A and Relative A were angry about
the injury and, after placing Youth A & Youth B in Relative A’s car,
started an argument then a physical altercation with Parent B’s
girlfriend. Parent A and Relative A had two guns, a knife, and
brass knuckles with them. Parent B sustained cuts as a result of
wrestling the knife away from Parent A, which Parent A
brandished after failed attempts to disengage the safety from a
gun she had.
5

Foster Care Worker reported she already had a TDM Meeting
scheduled for 2 days after the incident at which time the youths
were going to return to Parent B. During that meeting, it was
decided the youths would be moved from Relative A to Relative B
and the return home would be delayed while the incident was
investigated by law enforcement. Foster Care Worker stated she
arranged to have law enforcement present when she removed the
youths from Relative A’s home due to Relative A’s history as well
as Relative A and Parent A’s angry reactions during the TDM.
Foster Care Worker reported when she arrived to pick the youths
up from Relative A, no one was home. While in her car, Foster
Care Worker saw Relative A pull up, look at Foster Care Worker,
then drive off down the road. A short time later, Relative A
returned, but again tried to leave at which time law enforcement
and a DHHS Worker that had since arrived, used their cars to
block Relative A from leaving again. Foster Care Worker stated
Relative A did not have the youths in her car, rather, they were in
her home alone with Parent A, which is not allowed per court
order. Foster Care Worker was then able to transport the youths
to Relative B’s home. Approximately one week later, law
enforcement cleared Parent B of any charges, so it was
determined Youth A & Youth B would be returned to his home. On
the date and time Foster Care Worker had arranged to pick the
youth’s up from Relative B, neither Relative B nor the youths were
at Relative B’s home. Foster Care Worker called her Program
Manager to let her know. Either Program Manager or Director
spoke to Relative B after which Foster Care Worker was told by
Program Manager to leave and plan on picking the youths up the
following day.
On 2/15/2023, Parent B, who had used Relative A as a support,
asked Relative A to pick the youths up from daycare for him.
Relative A asked Parent B if she could keep the children for a little
while for a celebration after which Parent A texted Parent B and
told him they were not bringing the youths back to him and
blocked his number so he could not text or call back. Parent B
texted and called Foster Care Worker directly, rather than calling
the on-call number, so Foster Care Worker did not know about
this until the following day. Parent B had also called law
enforcement. Relative A and Parent A returned the youths to
Parent B on 2/16/2023.
Regarding visits, Foster Care Worker reported that Parent A’s
visits began occurring over Zoom due to the safety concerns
presented by the 10/30/2023 incident. In December of 2022,
Parent A’s visits moved to being in-person at Relative B’s home
6

and were supervised by agency staff. After two visits at Relative
B’s home, Parent A called Foster Care Worker on the day of her
scheduled visit and stated that Relative B was sick, so she wanted
to do the visit at Relative A’s home. Foster Care Worker stated
that there was not enough notice, so the visit was cancelled. The
next week, Parent A again called on the day of her scheduled visit
to say Relative B was sick and visits couldn’t be at her home
anymore then requested the visit take place at Relative A’s home.
Despite Foster Care Worker telling Parent A that the visit location
would not be changed at such short notice, Parent A then called
Case Aide and told her Foster Care Worker approved the location
change. Foster Care Worker cancelled the visit due to the
manipulation. Foster Care Worker stated Parent A refused to do
her visits at the agency and did not want either Foster Care
Worker or Case Aide at the visits. The court ordered supervised
visits, so Foster Care Worker had a discussion with Case Aide
about moving the visits to Relative A’s home. Foster Care Worker
stated that Case Aide was comfortable with supervising visits at
Relative A’s home. Foster Care Worker stated that the decision to
move the visits to Relative A’s home happened quickly. She
stated that she had been burned out from this case since
December of 2022 and Parent A was screaming and yelling at her
about the location. Foster Care Worker mistakenly thought she
had a conversation with her supervisor in which it was agreed to
move the visits to Relative A’s home. Visits took place in Relative
A’s home two or three times, without incident, until the 4/3/2023
visit.
Foster Care Worker stated that Parent A has “always been the red
flag” and that Relative A was always appropriate and has never
given the agency staff reason to make them feel unsafe. Foster
Care Worker stated this case was reassigned from her to Foster
Care Supervisor as of 4/6/2023. Foster Care Worker stated that
she requested the case be transferred to a different worker at
least 5 times prior to the transfer.
Program Manager was interviewed via Teams on 4/26/2023. She
reported she was aware of the incident that occurred on
10/30/2022; however, she was not aware that DHHS had made
findings. She stated the youths remained with Relative A until they
were returned to Parent B and were never removed from Relative
A. When I informed Program Manager during her interview the
youths had been removed per the worker’s interview as well as
MiSACWIS placement documentation, Program Manager replied
she did not know that had occurred. She reported she did not
know about Relative A leaving the youths alone with Parent A at
7

the time Foster Care Worker went to Relative A’s home to remove
the children or that Relative A had attempted to leave. Program
Manager stated she was not aware that an attempt was made to
pick up the youths from Relative B’s home, but they were not
present. She stated she would have been on leave on that date,
so Foster Care Worker’s statement that Program Manager told her
she could leave the youths wherever they were and try again the
following day was inaccurate. Program Manager wasn’t made
aware of the incident during which Relative B picked the youths up
from daycare and kept them overnight without permission until
after the 4/3/2023 incident.
Program Manager reported not knowing the decision was made to
begin having visits at Relative A’s house. She stated Relative A
should not have been present at visits following the 10/30/2023
incident and visits never should have occurred in her home due to
the volatility of the environment. Program Manger reported when
she found out that visits had been taking place in Relative A’s
home, Foster Care Worker and Case Aide told her that Parent A
did not want her visits at the office, so made the decision to
change the visit location to Relative A’s home. Program Manager
stated it’s problematic she is unaware of so many details of this
case and that the staff allowed Relative A to dictate the visits.
Program Manager reported these concerns are being addressed
through Human Resources and Parent A's visits are now
occurring at the agency office without Relative A present.
Director/Chief Administrator was interviewed via Teams on
4/27/2023. She reported she didn’t know that Parent A’s visits
were occurring at Relative A’s home until after the 4/3/2023 visit.
She stated there should have been a meeting with Foster Care
Worker and management before a decision was made regarding
allowing visits at Relative A’s home. She reported she recalled
talking to Relative B about the youths moving from her home to
Parent B due to Relative B not understanding that the youths were
court ordered to be returned to him and that they weren’t being
removed from her for any other reason. Director does not recall if
there was an issue with the youth’s not being at Relative B’s when
Foster Care Worker arrived to pick them up. She reported she
didn’t know about Relative A having picked up the youths from
daycare and keeping them overnight until after the 4/3/2023
incident. She stated the lack of communication in this case is
concerning and is being addressed.

Analysis Agency staff allowed visits to occur in Relative A’s home despite
Relative A participating in an assault involving weapons while
Youth A & Youth B were present, allowing Parent A to be with her
and the youths without permission, attempting to flee her home
when Youth A & Youth B were being removed from her care,
leaving Youth A & Youth B alone with Parent A against court
orders, and failing to return to youths to Parent A and keeping
them overnight with Parent A without permission. Allowing
visitation at Relative A's home did not assure for the safety and
well-being of Youth A & Youth B.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
